title: Companies Emerging From Bankruptcy Lean Into IT
text:
Technology leaders are playing a bigger role in helping companies bounce back after a bankruptcy.

Many are brought in as bankruptcy proceedings wind down and the company is going through a broader restructuring. Their tasks include forging information-technology strategies around cloud computing, data analytics and other advanced digital tools in order to cut costs and reignite productivity, senior IT executives and industry analysts say.

Chief information officers at restructured companies looking to jumpstart growth are in “an incredible position to drive change,” said Chris Pick, founder of the Technology Business Management Council, a nonprofit trade group for enterprise IT managers.

Mr. Pick, chief marketing officer at software maker Apptio Inc., said the spread of digital tools has enabled tech leaders to better track data and gain insights about customers and competitors. That allows them to ask “harder, smarter questions” about what needs to be done to breathe new life into a business, he added.

Michael Bailey, Catalina Marketing’s chief technology officer. Photo: Catalina Marketing

Michael Bailey, chief technology officer at Catalina Marketing Corp., which filed for chapter 11 protection in December, said the period immediately after bankruptcy has been “a great time for innovation.”

The St. Petersburg, Fla., company was a pioneer in data harvesting, collecting data about U.S. shoppers at cash registers for decades and using it to help consumer-goods companies tailor marketing campaigns.

Catalina named Mr. Bailey as CTO in February—the same day the company said it had completed its financial restructuring and was coming out of bankruptcy. His appointment was part of an effort to “efficiently transform the business,” Catalina said at the time.

Among other benefits, Mr. Bailey said the restructuring removed budgetary constraints that were slowing IT progress, allowing the company to think more broadly about its use of technology. That includes “significant investments” in efforts to scale computing power, strengthen data security and enhance its media platform to provide advanced targeting and real-time metrics for the company’s retail customers, he said.

“Like any business, costs are considered, but the overwhelmingly consistent goal is to enable Catalina’s future,” Mr. Bailey said: “These are exciting times.”

CIOs are in a unique position to boost productivity, drive down costs, streamline operational efficiency and create new sources of revenue, industry analysts said.

Since Caesars Entertainment Corp. ’s largest operating unit emerged from bankruptcy in late 2017, the company has cut the number of internal software applications to 260 from more than 800, thanks to an effort to improve IT efficiency, said CIO Les Ottolenghi.

Mr. Ottolenghi, who became the casino company’s IT chief in 2016—a year after the operating unit filed for bankruptcy under mounting debt—said his goals were “to define a technology platform, a unified technology operating system to scale our investments in technology and leverage our data to reduce costs and increase margin.”

To do that, the company initiated a cloud-first strategy, he said. That gave tech teams more capacity to automate back-office systems and develop new, real-time digital services for customers, such as automated check-in options and virtual-reality casino gambling, as a way of generating revenue, he added.

There were 5,470 commercial chapter 11 filings last year, down 5% from 2017, according to the American Bankruptcy Institute. Large cases can account for dozens of filings.

Mr. Pick said CIOs and other tech leaders who focus on the right metrics through strong data insights are guiding better corporate decision-making, enabling more companies to achieve goals and stay healthy.

description: Technology leaders are playing a bigger role in helping companies bounce back after a bankruptcy.
